name: fibre production, jute, retting | fibre, jute | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/20667/documentation

The dataset represents production of 1 kg jute fibre from harvested jute plant (fresh green matter.) ;Normally, jute retting activity involves immersion of the bundles of jute into stagnant water in the jute cultivation field, tanks, ponds, ditches etc., or in slow moving clear water in canals, rivulets, rivers etc. The minimum ratio of plant material to water in the case of a stagnant water body is 1:11. Jute stalk takes several days for retting and then the loosened fibre is extracted from the jute stalk which becomes the by-product of jute retting activity. The currently used process involves ribboning of green stems. After this the ribbons are immersed in Water. Ribboning greatly reduce material handling and water consumption. Retting takes place from  5-7 days. The retted ribbons are dried and the resulting reeds are then sent to spinning mills for spinning.;In India, since the retting activity is usually accomplished either on the jute growing field or in canals, and sometimes in rivers during the rainy season, the wastewater from the jute retting process gets either diluted by rainwater, or washed away. The environmental impacts of wastewater, from jute retting process are not significant, therefore they are not considered in this inventory. ;Another dataset "jute production, irrigated, IN” covering the cultivation activities has been provided as a separate dataset. Since jute retting is a natural process, no machine inputs are considered here in this process. 

Activity begins from ribboning of green jute plants


This activity ends with is 1 kg ribboned, retted and dried reeds of jute as a result of jute transformation process. The datasets includes use of water and electricity.
category: C:Manufacturing/13:Manufacture of textiles/131:Spinning, weaving and finishing of textiles/1311:Preparation and spinning of textile fibres

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The location of considered dataset is CRIJAF Barrackpore, area in the state of West Bengal, India. This region is the leader in jute production.The production and cultivation of jute is restricted mainly to the states, along the Ganga-Brahmaputra delta in West Bengal , Assam, Bihar and Orissa. Recently jute production has extended to other states as well. e.g. Meghalaya, Tripura etc.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: In India, the retting activity is usually accomplished either on the jute growing field or in canals, by immersion of the bundles of jute into stagnant water.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Primary data were taken from field visit and interviews and supported by review of literature where required. Information was provided by CRIJAF Barrackpore, West Bengal. Standardized questionnaire was developed and adapted to Jute specific processes. The secondary data from literature and the primary data from interview were compared and matched to obtain highest data quality.

exchanges.description: 170 kgs of water converted to m3. No wastewater output is considere as the retting process is usually accomplished on jute growing fields or in canals and the wastewater either gets diluted or washed away.
Dry retted fibre yield is 6.5% of total plant volume (fresh green matter).
